data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Trust is committed to ensuring continuity of employment for its staff and to use fixed-term or temporary contracts only for transparent and objective reasons where there is a genuine fixed-term need.

The aim of this policy is to explain the criteria for the use of a fixed-term contract; provide an overview of how fixed-term contracts will be managed within MSEFT; and specify the procedure required at the termination of a fixed-term contract.

The purpose of this policy is to ensure consistent and fair treatment of staff on fixed term contracts in accordance with the Fixed-term Employees (Prevention of Less Favourable Treatment) Regulations 2002 and ACAS Code of Practice 2013.

The policy applies to all Trust employees, including Medical and Dental staff. This policy is not applicable to Apprentices, students on work placement and temporary workers who do not have a contract of employment with the Trust.

Deanery doctors are primarily employed by the Deanery and therefore rotate from placement to placement. Therefore the Trust will not issue Deanery doctors notice of the end of their placement with the Trust unless the placement is terminated prematurely.

Bank workers may not be exempt from the (Prevention of Less Favourable Treatment) Regulations 2002; however, as MSE Bank workers are engaged on flexible agreements covering shift bookings on a casual worker basis, they will not be issued with notice.
This policy and procedure does not apply to external agency placements, consultancy or contractors positions.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to ensure that:

Employees on fixed term contracts are employed on the same terms and conditions as permanent employees, and in accordance with Agenda for Change or the appropriate Medical and Dental terms and conditions.
Employees on fixed term contracts are subject to the same policies and procedures as employees in substantive posts.
All benefits open to permanent employees are available to employees on fixed term contracts, provided the criteria is met as applicable for each benefit.
Fixed term employees are able to apply for suitable permanent vacancies within the Trust and have the opportunity to apply for the available vacancies in the same way as permanent staff.
Appropriate opportunities to enhance skills and career development are made available to all employees on fixed term contracts and the associated application process will be applicable.

Employees on fixed term contracts are protected against unfavourable treatment in line with legislation. Any non-extension of a fixed term contract complies with relevant legislation as outlined in 1.3 above.
All Fixed Term appointments will be subject to the probationary period as outlined in the Trust's Probationary Policy and Procedure.

Definitions

table_items.text: Employment contracts that are agreed for a fixed period, i.e. have a defined beginning and end date. They should only be used when circumstances make it inappropriate to employ an individual under a substantive contract.
The Fixed Term Employees (Prevention of Less Favourable Treatment) 2002
Current legislation governing fixed term appointments. The basis of the regulation is that employees on fixed term contracts should be treated no less favourably than their substantive counterparts

Incorporates the overall package of benefits, whether contractual or not, that a comparable substantive employee gets, or when it is offered on less favourable terms. It includes when an employer fails to do something for a fixed term employee that is done for a substantive employee. For example pay and annual leave entitlement (pro rata). Employees on fixed-term contracts are entitled to the same terms and conditions of employment on a pro-rata basis as the terms and conditions of a comparable substantive employee.
Staff with no contract end date (and staff with over 4 years' services where there is no justification for the individual to remain as fixed-term).

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Line Manager:
To make appropriate decisions regarding fixed term contracts and requesting a fixed term appointment only in appropriate circumstances.
To review the appropriateness of the contract on a regular basis in line with the needs of the service
To communicate clearly to the employee the end date of the contract and whether any extension has been sought or is obtained via the appropriate written correspondence
To ensure that financial approval is sought and obtained prior to the commencement of any fixed term contract recruitment or extension(s)
To ensure that all leaver processes are initiated in a timely fashion to avoid additional costs including salary overpayments or loss of Trust equipment or resources
Ensure that the procedure outlined in this document is followed.
Employee:

Employees on fixed term contract must ensure that they meet with their manager in accordance with the fixed term contract policy. Failure to comply with a manager's reasonable request to meet for this purpose will be dealt by the Trust's MSEPO-20222 Disciplinary policy.
Human Resources:

To keep a record of all staff on fixed term contracts and to notify a manager of the end date for an employee on a fixed term contract within good time to allow notice to be issued in accordance with the employee's terms and conditions.
When to consider a fixed term contract
The Trust is committed to only using fixed term contracts where there is a genuine service need to do so which can be objectively justified.
The Trust will normally consider a fixed term contract in the following circumstances:
Where the post requires specialist expertise or experience not available within MSEFT to support a short term project or task
Where the appointment is made to complete a temporary or time limited task within a stated period (project work)
To cover staff absence as appropriate, such as maternity, paternity and adoptive leave, career breaks, secondments etc.
Where the post is created by time related funding and the funds are available for a specified period only.
To provide additional cover during exceptionally busy periods.
Procedure
Approval to recruit for a fixed term contract must be completed in line with the Trust's Vacancy Control Panel authorisation process and MSEFT Recruitment and Selection Procedure
Advertising a Fixed-Term or Temporary Contract

6.1.1 When advertising  a  fixed  term vacancy  the advert  must  specify  the  length  of  the appointment (where this is unknown, the anticipated length must be specified) and the purpose of the contract. If there is a possibility of permanency or renewal on expiry of the stated period, this should also be included in the advert.
Filling a Vacancy from Fixed-Term to permanent:
6.2.1 Should a fixed-term post subsequently become possible to fill on a permanent basis, those permanent staff on the ‘At Risk' Register will be given prior consideration for the vacancy.

6.2.2 If there are no permanent employees on the ‘At Risk' Register, then the current fixed term post-holder would normally be offered a permanent contract provided that the following conditions are met:
They have 12 months or more continuous service, and
They were subject to an appropriate recruitment process (including a competitive interview) for that specific post at the outset and
That the possibility of it becoming permanent was made clear during the initial recruitment process,

6.2.3 If the fixed term post-holder does not meet the above criteria, the post should be advertised in accordance with normal recruitment procedures. The line manager should meet with the fixed-term employee to inform them that the post is due to be advertised, and if they are subsequently unsuccessful at interview, the dismissal process outlined below should be followed.
Extension of fixed-term contracts

6.3.1 In order to extend an existing fixed-term contract, after obtaining full authorisation including financial approval via the Trust Vacancy Panel, the manager should complete the appropriate change form and send it to the Workforce ESR team.
6.3.2 Following receipt of a signed change form, approved extensions or changes to the fixed term contract will be confirmed in writing to the employee by the Workforce ESR team.

6.3.2  Where an employee has accrued  4 years continuity of service on fixed-term  contracts with the same employer (these can be in different roles within different  service areas) they may automatically acquire substantive status, unless there is an objectively justifiable reason that this should not be the case (e.g. where a FTC is

Termination of fixed-term contract

6.4.1 The termination or non-renewal of a fixed-term contract beyond its expiry date may be deemed to be a dismissal by law. (Employment Rights Act 1996, s.95 (1) (b)) and the procedure outlined below should be followed.
6.4.2 The Trust will apply the following statutory dismissal procedure when a contract is not to be renewed:

1) The manager must formally invite the member of staff on a fixed term contract, inviting them to a meeting to discuss the expiry of the contract, giving 7 calendar days' notice of the date for the meeting. The letter will include a formal notification of the termination of the contract and confirm the right of the employee to be accompanied by a trade union representative or a work colleague (refer to Appendix 1)

data.url: MSEPO-21126 Fixed term contracts policy and procedure 1.0.005.png

data.text: The meeting should take place within  days of the invite letter being sent.

2) At the meeting the manager will confirm the reasons for the expiry of the fixed- term contract, e.g. the end of a project, and give appropriate notice. This meeting will also detail the opportunities for alternative employment that may be available.

3) Following the meeting, the manager will confirm in writing the discussion that took place and the reasons why the fixed-term contract will expire, issuing appropriate notice. This letter will also confirm the employee's right to appeal against the decision within  working days of receipt of the letter (refer to Appendix 2).

The minimum notification period before the contract is due to expire is determined by the length of an employee's contractual notice period. The manager should hold the meeting at least one month before their notice period is due to start.
Termination of fixed term contract on other grounds - SORS

6.5.1  Where managers need to end the fixed term contract before the end date specified in the contract of employment, for example if a change in funding occurs, they should contact their HR Business Partner in the first instance to ensure the correct process is followed. In such instances, the reason for ending the fixed term contract will be due to some other substantial reason and will follow the termination process as detailed in Section 6.4.

SOSR (Some Other Substantial Reason); e.g. where the requirement for the work to be undertaken has not reduced and the substantive post holder have returned to work or a permanent employee has been recruited. Examples of fixed-term employment ending on SOSR:
Exceptions to normal termination process for a fixed term contract

In certain circumstances it may not be appropriate to terminate a fixed term contract at its end date, for example if the employee is pregnant. In these circumstances please refer to the relevant policy and procedure for example – Maternity, Adoption and Parental Leave Guidelines.
Redundancy payments
6.7.1 Redundancy may apply where the requirement for the work to be undertaken has diminished or ceased. Examples of fixed-term employment ending due to redundancy:

Employee recruited to carry out the completion of a specific task, such as project work that is dependent upon external funding and the post will end once the funding ceases or no more funding can be found
A specific task which is then completed
Employee is recruited to provide additional staffing and the provision of services then reduces or ceases
In these cases the employee on a fixed term contract is not normally eligible for redundancy payment

6.7.2 Where an employee on a fixed-term contract has completed more than 2 years' continuous service at the time of termination of their fixed term contract, they will be entitled to the same redundancy rights as permanent staff.

Employees appointed on a fixed-term contract for less than 2 years, but who have continuous NHS service from another NHS organisation, will be eligible for a redundancy payment at the end of the fixed term contract, if the definition of redundancy is met.
For further information regarding redundancy, please see section  of the Agenda for Change handbook or seek advice from the Employee Relations team.
Appeal
An employee whose fixed term contract has not been renewed or extended has the right of appeal and this should be submitted to the Head of Employee Relations in line with the Trust's Appeal Policy.

This policy has been reviewed and approved by HR Policy Working Group and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust Intranet. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Human Resources team.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 3)
The Trust aim is to design and implement services, policies, procedures, needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that none are placed at a disadvantage over others.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be compliant with this assessment.
